author: skip

data:
Objectives 


After this Unit, you will be able to:
    - discuss what is right and wrong.  
    - ask for permission
    - set rules for your class
    - make yes/no questions
    - write profile of a famous person
author: skip

data:

data:
Exploration: Right and Wrong 

What do you do in the library?

Do you make noise?

Where do you cross the road?

How do you stand in school assembly?
author: skip

data: Sing this song together.
author: skip

data:
Listen and sing 

Would it be alright if I took your pen?
May I write and recite a poem then?
Of course, you can but rather do it soon.
I am so restless to wait till noon.

Can I take a photo with you somehow?
Is it alright if I click now?
Oh, I am afraid, I can't say 'yes' now.
Sorry, but I'd rather you not allow.
author: skip

data:
Listen and Sing 


Talk about a time when you were refused something. 

Talk in pairs and share your experiences.
author: skip

data:
Vocabulary 

strange: not known before; definitely out of the ordinary
unseen: never seen or perceived before; not observed
imprisonment: confinement in a prison or a jail as punishment
shattered: broken into many pieces
irritated: impatient, angry or displeased
release: set free
silly: lacking common sense or judgement
disappear: to get lost, or fade away
author: skip

data:
Reading: Three Simple Rules 

Read this story with the class.

Think about these questions:
      Where is the man?
      What is he holding in his hand?
      What is his name?

data: Topic: Reading I   (1 hour))
author: skip

data:
Reading - True or False? 

Chulong was satisfied with his riches.  True or False?
He bought a bird to keep at home.    True or False?
His greed set the bird free.           True or False?
The bird cheated Chulong.             True or False?
The bird changed its colour twice.     True or False?
author: skip
skip
data:
Library Rules 

      L  Listen to the librarian.
      I  Inquire (ask) if you need help.
      B  Be respectful of others.
      R  Read and talk quietly.
      A  Always walk, never run.
      R  Return books to their proper places.
      Y  Your manners are appreciated.

Libary Rules 

      L  Listen to the librarian.
      I  Inquire (ask) if you need help.
      B  Be respectful of others.
      R  Read and talk quietly.
      A  Always walk, never run.
      R  Return books to their proper places.
      Y  Your manners are appreciated.
author: skip
skip
data:
Classroom Rules 

Rule 1 -  Listen when your teacher is talking.
Rule 2 -  Follow directions quickly.
Rule 3 -  Respect others. Respect yourself. Respect your school.
Rule 4 -  Raise your hand to speak to the class.
Rule 5 -  Be safe. Be kind. Be honest.

     Be respectful.      Be responsible.      Be safe.

data:
Reading - discussion questions 

What was the main aim of Chulong?
Why could Chulong not make money from the bird?
What were the three simple rules the bird told to Chulong?
What type of person is Chulong?
What lesson did you learn from this story?
author: skip

data:
Writing 

Imagine that you were Chulong.

What would you do when the colourful bird changed into a black 
crow?

Write a few lines in your copy book about Chulong.
author: skip

data:
Topic: Speaking 

Read the next slides about Library Rules

and Classroom Rules.
author: skip

data:
Speaking 

Work in pairs. 
Read the library rules and classroom rules.
Talk to each other. 
Ask for permission and give or refuse permission.
author: skip

data:
Permission 

Asking for permission:       May I ......?
                               Can I .......?
                               Is it OK if I .......?

Giving permission:            Yes, you may.
                               Of course.
                               Yes, you can.

Refusing permission:         I'm sorry. You can't
                               I'm afraid you can't.
                               I'm sorry.
author: skip

 Objectives 

Students, your job is "TO DO” (not just “TO KNOW”)
During this lesson, show that you can: 
  (lesson planner: list concrete, measurable objectives here)
Examples:
A) Build an origami sailboat following instructions
     (not just ‘know about origami’).
B) Make a good question and answer with new words,
     (not just 'copy the words into your notebook).
C) Name 8 or more Himalayan mountains
     (not just know that Nepal has many mountains).

<----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+---->

 Reflection 


Encourage students to make personal connections, give

opinions, explain reasons, and draw conclusions, using questions

like the ones below : 

What did you/we learn? What were the most important ideas?

What do you think is the purpose or importance of this lesson?

What do you want to know more about?

Why do you care about...?

How might these new skills/ideas/formulas solve a problem?

How could this apply to a particular situation?

What did you learn that you'd like to share with others?

How can this new information be used in your community?

What do you think we will be learning next?

data:
Notes to Lesson Makers 
In grade 6 English, all the "units" have the same structure:
      getting started, reading 1, speaking, listening, grammar, 
      writing, reading 2, project, extra bit.

Print out the Teacher Guide for this Unit and follow it.
For "readings" type the text into a lesson text file, or if it is 
     long, ask Skip to make a PDF of the section of the textbook
For "pictures" ask Skip to import them
For "listening" record the text on your phone and send to Skip
For "quizzes", True/False tests, etc ask Skip to make a game
Add games, videos, PDF, ePaath, PhETs to augment your lesson

 Reflection 


Encourage students to make personal connections, give

opinions, explain reasons, and draw conclusions, using questions

like the ones below : 

What did you/we learn? What were the most important ideas?

What do you think is the purpose or importance of this lesson?

What do you want to know more about?

Why do you care about...?

How might these new skills/ideas/formulas solve a problem?

How could this apply to a particular situation?

What did you learn that you'd like to share with others?

How can this new information be used in your community?

What do you think we will be learning next?

data:
Notes to Lesson Makers 
In grade 6 English, all the "units" have the same structure:
      getting started, reading 1, speaking, listening, grammar, 
      writing, reading 2, project, extra bit.

Print out the Teacher Guide for this Unit and follow it.
For "readings" type the text into a lesson text file, or if it is 
     long, ask Skip to make a PDF of the section of the textbook
For "pictures" ask Skip to import them
For "listening" record the text on your phone and send to Skip
For "quizzes", True/False tests, etc ask Skip to make a game
Add games, videos, PDF, ePaath, PhETs to augment your lesson

<----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+---->

 Introduction 

Introduce topic of lesson 

Ask students:   

What do you know about _<this subject>_? Record answers

What would you like to know about _<subject>_? Record answers

Later in the lesson, make a list of What We Learned.

Possible student activities:

1) Predict vocabulary words for this lesson. 

2) Why is this topic important? Share answers with a partner, 

then with group.

Some other options: class discussion, pairs or group task, 

drawing, written responses
author: clone

data:
<----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+---->

 Objectives 

Students, your job is "TO DO” (not just “TO KNOW”)
During this lesson, show that you can: 
  (lesson planner: list concrete, measurable objectives here)
Examples:
A) Build an origami sailboat following instructions
     (not just ‘know about origami’).
B) Make a good question and answer with new words,
     (not just 'copy the words into your notebook).
C) Name 8 or more Himalayan mountains
     (not just know that Nepal has many mountains).

              verb (v) to repeat an activity

leader and provide the lesson reference.

 Reflection 


Encourage students to make personal connections, give

opinions, explain reasons, and draw conclusions, using questions

like the ones below : 

What did you/we learn? What were the most important ideas?

What do you think is the purpose or importance of this lesson?

What do you want to know more about?

Why do you care about...?

How might these new skills/ideas/formulas solve a problem?

How could this apply to a particular situation?

What did you learn that you'd like to share with others?

How can this new information be used in your community?

What do you think we will be learning next?

Notes to Lesson Makers 
In grade 6 English, all the "units" have the same structure:
      getting started, reading 1, speaking, listening, grammar, 
      writing, reading 2, project, extra bit.

Print out the Teacher Guide for this Unit and follow it.
For "readings" type the text into a lesson text file, or if it is 
     long, ask Skip to make a PDF of the section of the textbook
For "pictures" ask Skip to import them
For "listening" record the text on your phone and send to Skip
For "quizzes", True/False tests, etc ask Skip to make a game
Add games, videos, PDF, ePaath, PhETs to augment your lesson

<----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+---->

 Reflection 


Encourage students to make personal connections, give

opinions, explain reasons, and draw conclusions, using questions

like the ones below : 

What did you/we learn? What were the most important ideas?

What do you think is the purpose or importance of this lesson?

What do you want to know more about?

Why do you care about...?

How might these new skills/ideas/formulas solve a problem?

How could this apply to a particular situation?

What did you learn that you'd like to share with others?

How can this new information be used in your community?

What do you think we will be learning next?

data:
Notes to Lesson Makers 
In grade 6 English, all the "units" have the same structure:
      getting started, reading 1, speaking, listening, grammar, 
      writing, reading 2, project, extra bit.

Print out the Teacher Guide for this Unit and follow it.
For "readings" type the text into a lesson text file, or if it is 
     long, ask Skip to make a PDF of the section of the textbook
For "pictures" ask Skip to import them
For "listening" record the text on your phone and send to Skip
For "quizzes", True/False tests, etc ask Skip to make a game
Add games, videos, PDF, ePaath, PhETs to augment your lesson
author: clone

 Reflection 


Encourage students to make personal connections, give

opinions, explain reasons, and draw conclusions, using questions

like the ones below : 

What did you/we learn? What were the most important ideas?

What do you think is the purpose or importance of this lesson?

What do you want to know more about?

Why do you care about...?

How might these new skills/ideas/formulas solve a problem?

How could this apply to a particular situation?

What did you learn that you'd like to share with others?

How can this new information be used in your community?

What do you think we will be learning next?

Notes to Lesson Makers 
In grade 6 English, all the "units" have the same structure:
      getting started, reading 1, speaking, listening, grammar, 
      writing, reading 2, project, extra bit.

Print out the Teacher Guide for this Unit and follow it.
For "readings" type the text into a lesson text file, or if it is 
     long, ask Skip to make a PDF of the section of the textbook
For "pictures" ask Skip to import them
For "listening" record the text on your phone and send to Skip
For "quizzes", True/False tests, etc ask Skip to make a game
Add games, videos, PDF, ePaath, PhETs to augment your lesson

 Reflection 


Encourage students to make personal connections, give

opinions, explain reasons, and draw conclusions, using questions

like the ones below : 

What did you/we learn? What were the most important ideas?

What do you think is the purpose or importance of this lesson?

What do you want to know more about?

Why do you care about...?

How might these new skills/ideas/formulas solve a problem?

How could this apply to a particular situation?

What did you learn that you'd like to share with others?

How can this new information be used in your community?

What do you think we will be learning next?

data:
Notes to Lesson Makers 
In grade 6 English, all the "units" have the same structure:
      getting started, reading 1, speaking, listening, grammar, 
      writing, reading 2, project, extra bit.

Print out the Teacher Guide for this Unit and follow it.
For "readings" type the text into a lesson text file, or if it is 
     long, ask Skip to make a PDF of the section of the textbook
For "pictures" ask Skip to import them
For "listening" record the text on your phone and send to Skip
For "quizzes", True/False tests, etc ask Skip to make a game
Add games, videos, PDF, ePaath, PhETs to augment your lesson

author: clone

data:
<----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+---->

 Introduction 

Introduce topic of lesson 

Ask students:   

What do you know about _<this subject>_? Record answers

What would you like to know about _<subject>_? Record answers

Later in the lesson, make a list of What We Learned.

Possible student activities:

1) Predict vocabulary words for this lesson. 

2) Why is this topic important? Share answers with a partner, 

then with group.

Some other options: class discussion, pairs or group task, 

drawing, written responses
author: clone

data:
<----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+---->

 Objectives 

Students, your job is "TO DO” (not just “TO KNOW”)
During this lesson, show that you can: 
  (lesson planner: list concrete, measurable objectives here)
Examples:
A) Build an origami sailboat following instructions
     (not just ‘know about origami’).
B) Make a good question and answer with new words,
     (not just 'copy the words into your notebook).
C) Name 8 or more Himalayan mountains
     (not just know that Nepal has many mountains).
author: clone

data:
<----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+----+---->

 Vocabulary 


Students, during this lesson you will define and use:

List words & their definitions from Looma dictionary.

Highlight vocabulary in yellow. Examples:

    swing: noun (n) a hanging seat

           verb (v) to move or cause to move back and forth

    practice: noun (n) repetition of an activity

              verb (v) to repeat an activity

For words not yet in Looma's dictionary, tell your Looma 

leader and provide the lesson reference.
